G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This is a Complaint for Modification brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and the Court’s equitable powers, seeking modification of an existing custody and parenting time order on the grounds of a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare and best interests of the minor children.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting time pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 215, § 6; and applicable case law, including *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: "That portion of the judgment granting custody to the wife is reversed. The case is remanded to the Probate Court solely on that issue. *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a party seeking modification of a custody or parenting order must demonstrate (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a general custody-modification case. It repeatedly frames the standard solely as whether removal is in the children’s best interests and, although it quotes ALI Principles noting that relocation can be a ‘substantial change in circumstances,’ it does not articulate or apply a two-prong Massachusetts test requiring (1) material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment and (2) best interests of the child for all custody/parenting modifications. Thus it does not clearly establish the proposition claimed.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u.relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances … only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]… (4)… the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests….’”

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a party seeking modification of a custody or parenting order must demonstrate (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.

Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: This case is a removal/relocation decision made in the context of an original divorce and custody judgment, not a post‑judgment modification proceeding. The opinion nowhere states that a party seeking modification must show a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment plus best interests of the child; instead it discusses the ‘best interests’ standard and the ‘real advantage’ test for removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30. Thus it does not establish or affirm the specific two‑part modification standard described in the proposition.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this commonwealth … unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

*Scholl v. McLain*, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 27.relevant_excerpt: A distinction should be drawn between zoning schemes that, as here, simply contain an ambiguity as to which of a small, finite number of alternatives was intended, and those that are so inherently indefinite and vague as to violate constitutional principles. Zoning is entitled to a strong presumption of constitutional validity (Rosko v. Marlborough, 355 Mass. 51, 53 [1968]), and courts should be wary of declaring zoning fatally indefinite.

He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence.

App. Ct. 812 (1.support_reasoning: The case concerns a custodial parent’s request to remove children from Massachusetts to California and focuses on how to evaluate the children’s best interests in a removal context, emphasizing the welfare of the custodial parent and alternative visitation arrangements. *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The best interests of children for purposes of deciding whether to permit removal are also interwoven with the well being of the custodial parent, and the determination, therefore, requires that the interests of the mother also be taken into account. … We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests.”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595\.proposition: The Children’s exposure to yelling, intimidation, physical aggression, and police intervention constitutes a harmful and inappropriate environment, inconsistent with their best interests under Massachusetts law.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595\.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly recognizes that domestic violence and abuse within the family, witnessed or experienced by a child, cause a “distinctly grievous kind of harm” and must be weighed in custody determinations as affecting the child’s best interests. While the facts here include more severe and chronic violence than just yelling and intimidation, the Court’s reasoning broadly condemns intrafamily physical force and intimidation as fundamentally incompatible with the child’s right to physical security and as highly relevant to best-interests analysis. Thus it provides general authority that an environment of violence and police intervention is harmful and inappropriate under Massachusetts law, though it does not enumerate yelling or police calls as standalone categories.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595\.relevant_excerpt: “We endorse the Appeals Court’s commitment to the propositions that physical force within the family is both intolerable and too readily tolerated, and that a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm. … Quite simply, abuse by a family member inflicted on those who are weaker and less able to defend themselves … is a violation of the most basic human right, the most basic condition of civilized society: the right to live in physical security, free from the fear that brute force will determine the conditions of one’s daily life.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.proposition: The Children’s exposure to yelling, intimidation, physical aggression, and police intervention constitutes a harmful and inappropriate environment, inconsistent with their best interests under Massachusetts law.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the best-interests standard, statutory factors under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and stability/primary-caretaker considerations in custody determinations. It does not discuss yelling, intimidation, physical aggression, or police intervention, nor does it evaluate such conduct as creating a harmful or inappropriate environment. Consequently, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about exposure to domestic conflict and police involvement being contrary to children’s best interests.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Massachusetts courts are required to prioritize the safety and well‑being of children in custody and parenting matters. See, e.g., G.L. c. 208, § 31; G.L. c. 208, § 31A (requiring consideration of effects of abuse); *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (1998).

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A.proposition: The continuation of unsupervised parenting time in the presence of the Cohabitant, without any safeguards or restrictions, is not consistent with the Children’s best interests and is contrary to the protective purposes embodied in G.L. c. 209A and G.L. c. 208, § 31A.

This aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts courts must prioritize children’s safety and well‑being in custody and parenting matters.

G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The “best interests of a child” is a question that presents the trial judge “with a classic example of a discretionary decision.” ... [A] judge may consider a wide range of permissible evidence in determining which placement will serve the child’s best interests.

*Smith v. Joyce*, 421 Mass. 520, 524\u20.proposition: The continuation of unsupervised parenting time in the presence of the Cohabitant, without any safeguards or restrictions, is not consistent with the Children’s best interests and is contrary to the protective purposes embodied in G.L. c. 209A and G.L. c. 208, § 31A.
*Smith v. Joyce*, 421 Mass. 520, 524\u20.support_reasoning: The case does not support the claimed proposition. The SJC held that there was *insufficient* evidence to justify a 209A stay‑away order regarding the father’s contact with his children, and emphasized that independent support is required before restricting parent‑child contact. The opinion does not state that unsupervised parenting time with a cohabitant is inconsistent with the children’s best interests or contrary to G.L. c. 209A or c. 208, § 31A; instead, it cautions against imposing such restrictions without adequate evidence and findings.
*Smith v. Joyce*, 421 Mass. 520, 524\u20.relevant_excerpt: “There is no evidence that warranted an order barring the defendant from contact with his sons. The judge should have considered the defendant’s relations with his sons apart from the plaintiff’s request that the defendant stay away from her. If there is to be a G. L. c. 209A order that a defendant stay away from and have no contact with his or her minor children, there must be independent support for the order.… The defendant is entitled to have that portion of the June 29, 1993, order vacated that directs him to stay away from his sons.”

*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, Massachusetts courts consider, among other things, the child’s safety, the child’s emotional needs, the stability of each parent’s home environment, and any pattern of abuse or violence.
*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly explains that, beyond determining parental unfitness, the judge must consider the children’s best interests, including placement options, stability of home environments, emotional needs, and patterns of abuse/violence. It notes the mother’s history of abuse, unstable and unhealthy housing, inconsistent visitation, lack of insight into the children’s emotional needs, and emphasizes the importance of sibling relationships and maintaining children within the natural family. These factors align with the proposition that Massachusetts courts look to safety, emotional needs, stability of each home, and abuse/violence patterns in best‑interests determinations.
*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.relevant_excerpt: “The judge’s findings are adequate under this standard to support the removal of the children from the mother’s care. He found that she was a ‘disorganized, immature, irresponsible, inconsistent person whose inadequacies as a parent have deprived her children of the basic physical needs of food, clothing, shelter and basic emotional needs.’ … She has been unable to maintain steady employment or a stable home environment… She lacks insight into the children’s emotional needs and is therefore unable to provide them with the psychological nurturing they need.” (392 Mass. at 711-13)

*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182, 19.proposition: Courts have broad discretion to tailor parenting time conditions to address risks posed by third parties in the home, such as prohibiting contact between the child and a particular individual or requiring supervision of visits. See *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) (rescript); *Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182, 190–91 (1998) (upholding conditions on visitation to protect child).

Merida concerns child support, attachment of assets, and a change from shared to sole legal custody; it does not discuss parenting time/visitation conditions or restrictions aimed at third parties in the home. The only pertinent language is a general statement that Probate and Family Court judges have broad discretion in divorce matters to protect children’s interests, but it is in the context of financial security and college expenses, not tailoring visitation conditions or prohibiting contact with specific individuals. Thus, the case does not substantively support the specific proposition about conditioning parenting time based on third-party risks.
*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182, 19.relevant_excerpt: “A Probate and Family Court judge has ‘broad discretion to fashion judgments in divorce proceedings that will best protect the interests and welfare of the parties’ minor children.’ Pare v. Pare, 409 Mass. 292, 298–299 (1991). The exact form of the order (or the decision to enter an order at all) is also within the judge’s broad discretion.” 428 Mass. at 190.
